Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I:VIBES: An Intelligent Application for Emotional Support During the COVID-19 Crisis
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project includes the need for 1) student engagement in social-emotional learning, 2) coordinated and consistent ways for counselors, teachers, and students to support the mental health of students, and 3) student connection during times of isolation. The transition from elementary to middle school demands new social skills in a larger and more intricate environment with an increased probability of peer conflicts. Paradoxically, this point also marks a need for more stable and intimate relationships with peers. In other words, the point of highest need with respect to relationships coincides with opportunities for the most turmoil. All of these challenges now exist in parallel with COVID-19, which has caused school closings, food scarcity, parental unemployment, social isolation, and destabilized support systems. The project will develop a scalable tool for supporting teachers, counselors and after school/out of school facilitators engaging students in social-emotional learning. Within the web-based system, students will be able to actively and consistently track and reflect upon their thoughts, feelings, and emotions; teachers/counselors will have a dashboard with a view of studentsâ€™ challenges and customized suggestions for students to engage with social-emotional learning activities. <br/><br/>The proposed project will develop an intelligent online self-tracking system to support social-emotional growth for middle school students. The key technical challenges we must resolve include: defining and refining a user experience that teachers/counselors will find educationally compelling and with which learners will engage; designing a curating process for remote learning content that will ensure safety and security of all users; designing algorithms to support tracking of student social-emotional well-being; and creating a recommendation system that determines the best interventions to suggest to students based on previous interactions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The US has not effectively mitigated risks for poor mental, emotional, and behavioral healthoutcomes for youth, which can hinder their development and contribute to school dropout,incarceration, homelessness, and decreased economic well-being. While programs delivered inschools to teach social and emotional skills can benefit the healthy development of youth, thereis still a need for coordinated and scalable strategies that are effective in supporting individuals,families, and populations to address the needs of youth.

For this Phase I project, the DEEP Designs team developed VIBES (Virtual InteractionsBoosting Emotional Support), an intelligent online self-tracking system to supportsocial-emotional growth for middle and high school students. The platform focuses on emotionalself-awareness and decision making, which are a part of a nationally-utilized framework forhealthy youth development. VIBES provides engaging, culturally-relevant means for students toreport and reflect on their emotions and use artificial intelligence and visualizations to supportstudents and caring adults in spotting potentially negative patterns. Finally, VIBES usesalgorithms for recommending more personalized activities for counselors/teachers to use toencourage student social-emotional growth.

To better understand the potential opportunities for SEL applications to make a positive impactand to uncover potential issues, the team conducted customer discovery research, includingsemi-structured interviews with teachers, administrators, counselors, students, and parents. Intotal, 103 interviews were conducted via Zoom. The interviews revealed valuable insights intohow the VIBES platform could be used to address the needs of students, parents, andeducators, as well as potential issues that need to be addressed.

In conclusion, the VIBES platform has the potential to be a valuable resource for promotingsocial-emotional well-being for students in elementary and middle school, particularly in the faceof the fallout caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and other events affecting the social andemotional health of children. The platform offers a coordinated and scalable strategy forsupporting youth by actively engaging them while intelligently and scalably paying attention totheir emotional well-being.
